title: Stocks Edge Up With Inflation, Earnings in Focus; Tesla shares fall after electric-car maker cuts its full-year growth expectations
text:
Major central banks are expected to further lift interest rates during coming meetings as price pressures show little signs of easing. Inflation figures in the U.K. and Canada came in above expectations this week. Germany's producer prices rose strongly in September from a year earlier, driven by higher energy prices, the German statistics office Destatis said Thursday.

The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates five times this year and is likely to increase its benchmark federal-funds rate by another 0.75 percentage point at its meeting next month as it tries to bring down high inflation.

"At the moment, we keep getting upside surprises on inflation everywhere you look," said Hugh Gimber, a strategist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management. "No one really has a good grasp yet of where the central banks—particularly the Fed—are going to be able to stop [raising rates]."

Investors are also trying to assess if higher inflation and tightening financial conditions will feed through to earnings season. Mr. Gimber said he is paying attention to how companies are affected by wage pressure and higher input costs and if those costs can be passed on to consumers.

U.K. assets gained after British Prime Minister Liz Truss said Thursday she would resign, following weeks of political turmoil. The yield on the benchmark 10-year U.K. government bond fell to 3.824% from 3.876% Wednesday, while the British pound rose 0.4% against the dollar.

Tesla shares fell about 8% after the electric-car maker cut its full-year growth expectations. Whirlpool and Snap are slated to post quarterly results after the market close.

Shares of AT&T added 7.7% after the telecommunications giant raised its outlook for profit and wireless revenue.

Fresh data from the Labor Department showed that 214,000 workers filed for unemployment benefits in the week ended Oct. 15, down from the week prior. The National Association of Realtors will report sales of previously owned homes in September at 10 a.m. ET.

In bond markets, the yield on benchmark 10-year Treasurys ticked up to 4.158% from 4.127% Wednesday. Yields and prices move inversely.

In energy markets, Brent crude, the international benchmark, added 1.1% to $93.44 a barrel.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.3%.

In Asia, major indexes closed with losses. Hong Kong's Hang Seng declined 1.4%. South Korea's Kospi and Japan's Nikkei 225 each shed 0.9%.

The Japanese yen hit a 32-year low of 150 to the dollar. Japan's currency has fallen this year as its central bank has vowed to keep its monetary policy ultraloose.

Write to Caitlin Ostroff at caitlin.ostroff@wsj.com

Stocks Edge Up With Inflation, Earnings in Focus
